{"pk": 10, "path": "0001000100010004", "depth": 4, "numchild": 0, "title": "Hello world", "draft_title": "Hello world", "slug": "hello-world", "content_type": 29, "live": false, "has_unpublished_changes": true, "url_path": "/home/blog/hello-world/", "owner": 1, "seo_title": "", "show_in_menus": false, "search_description": "", "go_live_at": null, "expire_at": null, "expired": false, "locked": false, "first_published_at": null, "last_published_at": null, "latest_revision_created_at": "2019-10-24T07:56:27.396Z", "live_revision": null, "date": "2019-10-24", "intro": "Some hows and whys of me being here", "body": "

This is my first real post \u2014\u00a0i.e. not a lorem ipsum test post \u2014 on this new blog of mine. I'm excited! As I write this, I'm not actually finished building the site. (Not even slightly.) I started the Wagtail tutorial a couple of weeks ago. With the exception of the Django Girls tutorial, which I've basically only kept so that I have something on my GitHub, it's the first blog I've built.

So, why am I starting this new blog?

  1. The old one is... well, old.
    I started it in 2012. Although in some ways I am fundamentally the same person, there are even more ways in which I'm not.
  2. I'm pivoting careers.
    This summer, I decided I wanted to learn more about web & software development. This month, I decided I wanted to make it my career. I had my Rubicon moment (will be writing a post specifically about that soon). Anyway, I've been reading a lot of material targeted towards people starting coding careers, and one almost universal piece of advice is: start a blog. Luckily, I'm pretty good at documenting stuff already, so of course the opportunity to write and reflect even more was one that I was going to take up straight away.
  3. I want a decent web app to show off. One that I'm actually going to be using, updating, etc.
    See above. No good trying to becoming a dev if there's nothing you've actually dev'd.

", "tagged_items": [{"pk": null, "tag": 1, "content_object": 10}], "gallery_images": []}

{"pk": 10, "path": "0001000100010004", "depth": 4, "numchild": 0, "title": "Hello, world!", "draft_title": "Hello world", "slug": "hello-world", "content_type": 29, "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "url_path": "/home/blog/hello-world/", "owner": 1, "seo_title": "", "show_in_menus": false, "search_description": "", "go_live_at": null, "expire_at": null, "expired": false, "locked": false, "first_published_at": "2019-10-24T08:16:23.475Z", "last_published_at": "2019-10-24T08:21:45.441Z", "latest_revision_created_at": "2019-10-24T08:21:45.395Z", "live_revision": 21, "date": "2019-10-24", "body": "

Hi! You may be familiar with my old blog. Fear not, for you can still access the archives here. But for reasons that will become clear as you read my last post there, it seems natural to lay that one to rest and have a new focus.

There are the three main reasons I\u2019m writing this here now:

  1. The old one is\u2026 well, old.
    I started it in 2012. Although in some ways I am fundamentally the same person, there are even more ways in which I\u2019m not.
  2. I\u2019m pivoting careers.
    This summer, I decided I wanted to learn more about web development so that I could do my job better. This month, I decided I wanted to heavily integrate it into my career. I had my Rubicon moment (will be writing a post specifically about that soon).
    Anyway, I\u2019ve been reading a lot of material targeted towards people starting coding careers. One almost unanimous piece of advice is to start a blog. It turns out that if you\u2019re going to learn to code, you have to give it your all. You can\u2019t be casual, because not only is there a load of new information to take in, it is also a massive learning curve and so much of this will be through trial and error. Luckily, I\u2019m pretty good at documenting stuff already, so of course the opportunity to write and reflect even more was one that I was going to take up straight away.
  3. I want a decent web app to show off.
    One that I\u2019m actually going to be using and updating; that isn\u2019t just there to fill up space on GitHub. See above. No good trying to becoming a dev if there\u2019s nothing you\u2019ve actually dev\u2019d.

I still had a load of drafts and ideas for my old blog, so I\u2019m also going to be writing about some non-coding topics here as well. But at the moment, this is where my main focus lies.

", "tagged_items": [{"pk": null, "tag": 1, "content_object": 10}], "gallery_images": [], "categories": []}

Hi! You may be familiar with my old blog. Fear not, for you can still access the archives here. But for reasons that will become clear as you read my last post there, it seems natural to lay that one to rest and have a new focus.

I've been using Wagtail to build this new blog. As both a professional content manager and an aspiring developer, I really it like so far. You will be reading this when it's deployed (read: live) and thus in a semi-passable aesthetic state, but as I write this post, the blog is not finished \u2014 not even slightly. But I look forward to when it is up for the world to see, and to be honest, I'm even more looking forward to having the autonomy and skills to make it work and look however I want.

There are three main hows and whys for all this:

  1. The old blog is\u2026 well, old.
    I started it in 2012. Although in some ways I am fundamentally the same person, there are even more ways in which I\u2019m not.

{"pk": 10, "path": "0001000100010004", "depth": 4, "numchild": 0, "title": "Hello, world!", "draft_title": "Hello, world!", "slug": "hello-world", "content_type": 29, "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "url_path": "/home/blog/hello-world/", "owner": 1, "seo_title": "", "show_in_menus": false, "search_description": "", "go_live_at": null, "expire_at": null, "expired": false, "locked": false, "first_published_at": "2019-10-24T08:16:23.475Z", "last_published_at": "2019-11-02T14:22:59.613Z", "latest_revision_created_at": "2019-11-02T14:22:59.548Z", "live_revision": 72, "date": "2019-10-24", "body": "

Hi! You may be familiar with my old blog. Fear not, for you can still access the archives here. But for reasons that will become clear as you read my last post there, it seems natural to lay that one to rest and have a new focus.

I've been using Wagtail to build this new blog. As both a professional content manager and an aspiring developer, I really it like so far, and not just because of the cute birdie. You will be reading this when it's deployed (read: live) and thus in a semi-passable aesthetic state, but as I write this post, the blog is not finished \u2014 not even slightly. But I look forward to when it is up for the world to see, and to be honest, I'm even more looking forward to having the autonomy and skills to make it look and work however I want.

There are three main hows and whys for all this:

  1. The old blog is\u2026 well, old.
    I started it in 2012. Although in some ways I am fundamentally the same person, there are even more ways in which I\u2019m not.

  2. I\u2019m pivoting careers.
    This summer, I decided I wanted to learn more about web development so that I could do my job better. This month, I decided I wanted to heavily integrate it into my career. I had my Rubicon moment (will be writing a post specifically about that soon).
    Anyway, I\u2019ve been reading a lot of material targeted towards people starting coding careers. One almost unanimous piece of advice is to start a blog. It turns out that if you\u2019re going to learn to code, you have to give it your all. You can\u2019t be casual, because not only is there a load of new information to take in, it is also a massive learning curve and so much of this will be through trial and error. Luckily, I\u2019m pretty good at documenting stuff already, so of course the opportunity to write and reflect even more was one that I was going to take up straight away.

  3. I want a decent web app to show off.
    One that I\u2019m actually going to be using and updating; that isn\u2019t just there to fill up space on GitHub. See above. No good trying to becoming a dev if there\u2019s nothing you\u2019ve actually dev\u2019d.

I still had a load of drafts and ideas for my old blog, so I\u2019m also going to be writing about some non-coding topics here as well. It'll be a good mix. But at the moment, this is where my main focus lies.

{"pk": 15, "path": "000100010003", "depth": 3, "numchild": 0, "title": "About", "draft_title": "About", "slug": "about", "content_type": 34, "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "url_path": "/home/about/", "owner": 1, "seo_title": "", "show_in_menus": false, "search_description": "", "go_live_at": null, "expire_at": null, "expired": false, "locked": false, "first_published_at": "2019-10-31T10:48:16.825Z", "last_published_at": "2019-11-02T14:13:53.634Z", "latest_revision_created_at": "2019-11-02T14:13:53.593Z", "live_revision": 68, "body": "

NOW:

I'm a Content & QA Manager learning web development (focussing on Python & Django).

Formerly, I worked both in-house and freelance as a writer, editor (English), and translator (German to English). I thought it was my dream job, but things changed! Anyway, because I'm apparently a glutton for punishment, I'm editing the first draft of my novel manuscript and researching for a non-fiction/memoir project.

In another life, where I had the right connections, money/inclination to spend >3 hours on an aeroplane, and stamina to live in -30\u00b0C temperatures, I'd be translating French Canadian literature.

Otherwise, you can find me devouring as many books as time allows.

HISTORY:

2002\u20132009 Secondary education in West Norfolk, England

2009\u20132013 BA degree in French & German @ University of Leicester, including semesters in Li\u00e8ge, Belgium and Linz, Austria; named top graduate in German

2013\u20132014 British Council language assistantship in Rimouski, Quebec

2014\u00a0Relocation to Berlin, Germany

"}

{"pk": 15, "path": "000100010003", "depth": 3, "numchild": 0, "title": "About", "draft_title": "About", "slug": "about", "content_type": 34, "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "url_path": "/home/about/", "owner": 1, "seo_title": "", "show_in_menus": false, "search_description": "", "go_live_at": null, "expire_at": null, "expired": false, "locked": false, "first_published_at": "2019-10-31T10:48:16.825Z", "last_published_at": "2019-11-02T14:45:50.708Z", "latest_revision_created_at": "2019-11-02T14:45:50.537Z", "live_revision": 87, "body": "

I'm a Content & QA Manager learning web development, with a focus on Python & Django.

Formerly, I worked both in-house and freelance as a writer/editor (English) and translator (German to English). For a while I thought it was my dream job, but things changed! Turns out I enjoy writing a lot more when I don't have to worry so much about making money from it or clients liking it, so I'm editing the first draft of my novel manuscript and researching for a memoir project.

In another life, in which I possessed the right connections, a driving licence, the money & inclination to spend >3 hours on an aeroplane, and tolerance of -30\u00b0C temperatures, I would be translating French Canadian literature.

Otherwise, you can probably find me devouring as many books as time allows.

HISTORY

2002\u20132009: Secondary education in West Norfolk, England

2009\u20132013: BA degree in French & German @ University of Leicester, including semesters in Li\u00e8ge, Belgium and Linz, Austria; named top graduate in German

2013\u20132014: British Council language assistantship in Rimouski, Quebec

2014:\u00a0Relocation to Berlin, Germany

"}

{"pk": 15, "path": "000100010003", "depth": 3, "numchild": 0, "title": "About", "draft_title": "About", "slug": "about", "content_type": 34, "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "url_path": "/home/about/", "owner": 1, "seo_title": "", "show_in_menus": false, "search_description": "", "go_live_at": null, "expire_at": null, "expired": false, "locked": false, "first_published_at": "2019-10-31T10:48:16.825Z", "last_published_at": "2019-11-02T18:45:07.586Z", "latest_revision_created_at": "2019-11-02T18:45:07.558Z", "live_revision": 95, "body": "

{"pk": 3, "path": "00010001", "depth": 2, "numchild": 5, "title": "die Webmeisterin", "draft_title": "die Webmeisterin", "slug": "home", "content_type": 2, "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "url_path": "/home/", "owner": null, "seo_title": "", "show_in_menus": false, "search_description": "", "go_live_at": null, "expire_at": null, "expired": false, "locked": false, "first_published_at": "2019-10-16T20:54:08.549Z", "last_published_at": "2019-11-09T11:27:55.986Z", "latest_revision_created_at": "2019-11-09T11:27:55.288Z", "live_revision": 109, "body": "

My name's Rosamund and I live in Berlin, Germany. I'm a recovering professional words person (translation, copywriting, journalism, editing) on the way to becoming a professional code person.

This blog is where you can follow my journey and find out why this isn't as much of a career U-turn as you might imagine.

A note on the blog name:

Webmeisterin would be a German approximation of "webmistress", which in turn would be a feminised version of "webmaster". Since the German verb for "to weave" is weben, the word Webmeisterin could also mean a woman who excels at weaving. Which is also kind of appropriate, as textile-based handicrafts have traditionally been seen as women's work, and these days the IT sector is very much dominated by men, and I want to do my part in disrupting that.

"}

{"pk": 3, "path": "00010001", "depth": 2, "numchild": 5, "title": "die Webmeisterin", "draft_title": "die Webmeisterin", "slug": "home", "content_type": 2, "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "url_path": "/home/", "owner": null, "seo_title": "", "show_in_menus": false, "search_description": "", "go_live_at": null, "expire_at": null, "expired": false, "locked": false, "first_published_at": "2019-10-16T20:54:08.549Z", "last_published_at": "2019-11-09T11:44:43.677Z", "latest_revision_created_at": "2019-11-09T11:44:43.543Z", "live_revision": 120, "body": "

My name's Rosamund and I live in Berlin, Germany. I'm a recovering professional words person (translation, copywriting, journalism, editing) on the way to becoming a professional code person.

This blog is where you can follow my journey and find out why this isn't as much of a career U-turn as you might imagine.

A note on the blog name:

Webmeisterin is a German approximation of "webmistress", which in turn is a feminised version of "webmaster". A webmaster is an actual profession; the description varies, but it's essentially someone who manages the entirety of a (small) organisation's IT operations. A bit vague, don't you think?

Since weben is also the German word for "to weave", the word Webmeisterin could also mean a woman who excels at weaving. Which is also kind of appropriate, as textile-based handicrafts have traditionally been seen as women's work, and these days the IT sector is very much dominated by men. I want to leave my female, queer mark on it. We shouldn't be striving for diversity for the sake of #diversity, but instead be truly welcoming and ready to embrace all the ways in which the variety of human life can enrich tech.

"}
